header: "My Girl Barely Saw Other Children in the Lockdown"
article:
How are other Europeans doing in the pandemic? In Paris, a mother is worried about her daughter: Since spring, she has been afraid of strangers.
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch.
How are our European neighbors doing in the pandemic? What is life like
these days in France, Ireland, Bulgaria and elsewhere? In the series "We
Neighbors", Europeans will be talking about their everyday lives: the taxi
driver in Dublin, the mother in Paris working from home, the theater family in
Bulgaria. They are also all taking part in Europe Talks, a discussion event for
which ZEIT ONLINE, together with media partners from 15 countries, is
registering participants. On Dec. 13, thousands of people from across Europe
will meet another European to discuss and debate the corona crisis.
"I
have noticed that the lockdown has changed people. On one hand, for the better.
They have more time to reflect: What are the really fulfilling aspects of my
life? How much importance should I attach to my job? People have more time to
read, to exercise, things that often fall by the wayside in our hectic,
day-to-day lives.
But
they have also changed for the worse. During the first lockdown in spring, my
husband and I worked from home, and we also had our daughter at home with us.
She was just one-and-a-half years old and the daycare centers were closed. She
is at an age in which she needs a huge amount of attention to develop. She is
too young to understand that you sometimes just have to shut the door when
you're working. It's not exactly easy for us.
My
girl is a very sociable child. During the first lockdown, she barely saw other
children at all. When were allowed to go out again afterward and the daycare
centers reopened, she was a little bit afraid when she saw other children. She
no longer actively approaches strangers like she used to. Plus, there are
parents who are telling their children to avoid people they don't know to the
extent possible. It does something to children – to people in general – when
they approach others and are seen as a potential danger. When they feel the
rejection.
It
concerns me. What kind of life is it for our children when they only see people
in masks? They aren't learning how to read emotions on people's faces, at least
that's what the experts are saying. It's especially important in the first
years of life. I have heard of children who pull their parent's mask back up
over their nose if it slides down. They have apparently started accepting
masked faces as being completely normal.
I
had just started a new job with a software provider when the pandemic started
in March. I was never able to get to know my colleagues in person. I only met a
few of them during my job interview. I miss the human contact aspect of work –
of exchanges that go beyond the purely functional.
I
used to work as a management consultant in Paris, and I learned a lot about how
companies change when they shift toward digitalization. During the pandemic,
more happened on this front in just a brief amount of time than in all the
years that came before! There is a meme that is being passed around the French
internet at the moment: "Who pushed through digitalization in your
company? The CEO? Or COVID-19?" It's actually pretty accurate. Prior to
the pandemic, a lot of companies were opposed to allowing their employees work
from home. Now, though, they have been forced to change just to survive.
Since
the beginning of the pandemic, there has been a lot of criticism of the
government in France – the approach to masks, for example, especially during
the first lockdown. First, we were told: Don't wear them. Then, we were allowed
to wear them if we wanted. Later, we were told not to buy them because there
wouldn't be enough for medical workers. And now, we are required to wear them.
All of us. Inside, of course, but there are now also streets in Paris where you
have to wear them outside as well. But in other streets, you don't. That makes
no sense. Still, I understand that the government can only make decisions based
on the current state of knowledge.
The
first lockdown in spring was really difficult for us. There was a time when you
could only leave your home with a permission form. It was extremely strict, but
understandable. Some things, though, were simply incomprehensible. At some
point, you were no longer allowed to take a walk in the forest. You could go to
the beach, but you couldn't go surfing. Those things have since been rectified,
but many people are still confused. What are we allowed to do? What really
helps? What measures are just contrived?
France was hit especially hard by the second wave of the pandemic. In the fall, case numbers rose steeply, with up to 60,000 new infections registered each day. Since the beginning of the pandemic, more than 50,000 people have died in the country, which has a population of 67 million.
The French government reacted to the second wave with drastic measures, many of which are still in place today. People in France are only allowed to leave their homes if they have a good reason to do so, such as going to work or to do the shopping. You are only allowed to go on walks or exercise for three hours a day and within a 20-kilometer radius of your home. Until recently, you could only exercise for one hour within a one-kilometer radius. Some shops have now been allowed to reopen, but they have to follow strict hygiene guidelines.
The strict lockdown resulted in a sharp reduction in the number of cases. Recently, there have only been around 15,000 new infections each day. It is expected that measures will be further relaxed in December.
 
In
the middle of October, when the case numbers were still lower, we flew to
Casablanca on vacation to visit my family. I was born in Morocco. We were
looking forward to a nice family vacation. But then, the second lockdown was
announced in France shortly after we arrived in Morocco. It took us completely
off guard. Our return tickets were cancelled, so we have extended our stay in
Morocco until Christmas. The numbers have been climbing in Casablanca since
summer. There is an 8 p.m. curfew and your temperature is taken before you are
allowed to go into shops. We just have to wait until the vaccine arrives.
A
lot of people in France are worried about civil rights and autocratic
tendencies during the pandemic. Recently, for example, when the government
passed a law forbidding the sharing of photos and videos of police officers
during an operation. It was allegedly to protect their safety. But people are
wondering: What kinds of things are taking place that I'm not supposed to know
about?
France
is a centralized state. Paris is everything and everything is in Paris. It's
where decisions for the entire country are made. People don't like it. There
are some mayors who are trying to resist and are reopening bars in their cities
on their own, for example.
And
then there is Dr. Didier Raoult, a doctor and microbiologist from Marseille in
the South of France. Marseille and Paris: The two cities have a long rivalry –
in football, in history and in culture. That could be one reason why Dr. Raoult
is so popular. He isn't just another expert from Paris who spouts the
government line. Raoult has a quite a striking beard and "tells it like it
is." Early on in the pandemic, he was appointed to the government's team
of scientific advisers. But he resigned a short time later. He then began
claiming that he could heal COVID-19. Still, many people listen to what Raoult says.
Since
the beginning of the pandemic, the thing I have missed most is travel. I was
always on the road a lot and I have friends around the world. I miss them. My
family and I have come up with a new tradition. Every two weeks, we pick a
country to travel to inside our apartment. Mexico, for example. We cook Mexican
food, listen to Mexican music and call friends in Mexico via video chat.
Virtual traveling, if you will. It's not quite as nice as real travel, but it's
the best we can do at the moment."
Translated by Charles Hawley and Daryl Lindsey
